If you loved turtling in StarCraft 1 / Broodwar, this is your game (but different)!  I played (and enjoyed) the campaign first, which got a mixed review upon release from those with experience playing the randomized missions.  It's just so. slow. with some BS achievements.  My <10 year old kids hated it, found it boring.

Graphics are not 3D.  Palette is morose.  Difficulty feels high at first; while you can save for the night and come back... it's "rogue-like" in that you can't restore a mid-mission save and between-mission tech tree is permanent (with some bad choices).   You can legit save backups between missions, but it's awkward in how it works and the name carries forward. If you're not a fan of wasting your time, turn off Steam cloud (at your own risk) and manually back up save files while out of the game.  There's no real tutorial.  It helped to watch a few good players on Youtube.  Things that really helped me push through on 100% 'Challenging' in my first playthrough (did drop final mission to 50% because I already had my 10k achievement in the bag, and was glad I did):
- Tents are the priority for both building and defending.  You can build them in rows of two.
- Reviewing the maps ahead of time (on the wiki) is common sense.  Where is stone?  Where is iron?  Wouldn't hurt to review recommended techs, either.
- Patrol works in lieu of a wall before the first swarms.
- One contiguous wall is enough for the first few missions, only if you build random wall bits in front of it.  Any randomly placed as 'scratching posts' are a great early warning system, when wood is scarce.  Zombies are dumb and will take the shortest empty-map path to your command center.  Take note if that means they will clump to which side of your wall.
- In general, expand from one choke point to the next, placing walls between clumps of rock or trees.  Middle mouse button to toggle grid view to confirm if your walls are contiguous.  They did a nice job with 'houses you build generate gold' so that expansion is wherever you want, rather than just where the StarCraft minerals are.
- Build your houses in tidy rows of two, with a space before the next row of two, ideally so that the alleyway between is in the direction that troops may need to move quickly.
- The swarm is always bigger than you think.  Tells you in the bottom left when the next official swarm is coming.  When there's no more listed there, there's no more official swarms to worry about.
- Soldiers can handle everything, but clumping them causes 'zeds' from very far away to rush towards you (and through your base if that's in the way of their path to the soldiers).  Noise is additive per tile, takes a moment to decay away, and stretches much farther than you can see.

I made it through on 100% 'Challenging' difficulty by trying things out and watching YouTubers like Kensei play on enhanced difficulties.  Wouldn't have realized how to do a lot of the above without it.  But after getting past the first 'no swarm until Day 60' missions I found watching those ahead hurt my enjoyment so I stopped (and just checked the wiki map image for where resources/ paths lead).  Still looked up tech tree upgrade suggestions, though.  The game obviously isn't that forgiving and doesn't respect your time... would have preferred an early option in the campaign to be like "I enjoy roguelikes" versus "Starting over repeatedly is for people without other games to play".  This game would have benefited from prebuilt tutorials and the ability to manually save mid-level.  Even so, my kids got bored of it because it is a very slow game even when you are winning.

PS. Foundry collectibles have changed since the guides 5 years ago.  Can't click 3 items in the northeast office and missing 20 empire points?  Find it in the northwest office, for me it was a floor book to the south of that room.  Possibly a couple of other hero mission collectibles changed.

Survival note to self:
Challenging and challenging went to wave on day 93 before special infected (and coming from all sides), and gave a score factor of 80%.

They are Billions is when you take the idea of tower defense, flip it on its head, add colony management to it and then throw a horde mechanic towards the player and yell "Have fun with that one, A**hole!".

You min max or you die. You kite or you die. You build the RIGHT colony or you die. You build efficient or you die. You skill proper or you die.

I think the one thing the game really has going for it that if you end up failing it doesnt spell disaster. Your save file doesnt get erased. You dont lose any progress other than on the level you played on. You can even reset the entire research tree at no cost whatsoever so you can experiment with what you may be wrong about. That is until you won a game with it. Then you can get screwed on that lol

Now would I say that the game is worth 30 bucks? Well it is 6 years old. And the gameplay isnt the most entertaining. Its more a case of "Lock in and enjoy". So if you are that kinda person? Yea it is. If not, wait for a sale.

They Are Billions (TAB) is a really fun but brutally unforgiving mix of light RTS and light tower defence.

You start off with a humble town hall and a handful of units, then slowly expand your settlement across a map absolutely crawling with zombies of all kinds. Every few days, a massive swarm will come crashing into your defences, and it’s entirely up to your hastily built walls, towers, and soldiers to hold the line, all while juggling your city’s economy and resources.

The real kicker? It only takes one stray, basic zombie slipping through your defences to trigger a chain reaction that turns your proud metropolis into yet another undead wasteland. One minute you’re admiring your growing city, the next you’re watching it collapse in a glorious domino effect of panic, fire, and screaming.

There’s a good variety of zombies to keep you on your toes. Everything from the shambling basics to nightmare special infected that run at mach 10 and chew through your defences like paper. Thankfully, you’ve got a growing roster of units, towers, and upgrades to counter them, from simple rangers with bows to powerful snipers, Tesla towers, mech units and more.

The campaign is fantastic too, easing you in by gradually introducing new buildings, units, and zombie types as you progress. It strikes a nice balance between teaching you the ropes and still punishing every mistake in spectacular fashion.

It’s stressful, it’s punishing… and it’s brilliant.

Decent game with some flaws.
Pathfinding is very basic and it becomes a problem when your troops fight in a group. The ones at the back don't move around the front ones and the ones at the front are unable to move around  the group when you want to save it after tanking zombies, especially Venoms.
Game does a poor job of providing information. The stats of the buildings, especially towers are hidden from us in the technology tree and we have to manually mouse over towers to check for tower ranges whereas I would have preferred if turning on life bars would also show the range of towers too. Also, that should have been a toggle instead of having to hold it down for the sake of QOL
Map layouts sometimes don't make sense. How on earth did humans manage to set up rail tracks and a damn HQ whilst surrounded by zombie hordes? The very last mission is the worst example. All this trouble just to build next to the fallen statue?? Why?

I like this game, but it is very hard.  I would almost liken it to the Dark Souls of RTS.  Maybe I just suck at it, but on the hard/200% difficulty I still haven't finished the campaign as of this review.  Yes, I could lower the difficulty anytime but I don't want to quit if I don't have to.  
The game is very unforgiving, if you lose a level, start all over, no restarting from a certain point in the level.  The only exception is if you save and quit you can come back to it (like you started a level, got about halfway through realized you had to get off the computer, you can save it and return from that point), but if you die, you go back.  The reason I think why is because, the game counts how many zombies you kill and adds to the overall total that all players of the game have killed.  That's one upside, if you killed a bunch of zombies in a level but you lost the zombies you killed still counts towards that and zombie kill achievements.     
During the campaign you get tech points to get new and improve current units and buildings.  However, once you pick the technology you're stuck with it, (if you pick it on the menu you can change it around or take it back, but once you leave that screen you're locked in,)  so if you don't like the unit or building you bought you have to use it or live with it.  
I think there's ways to save your campaign progress right before picking tech and if it doesn't work you can go back, but it's not intuitive.  
There's also survival levels aside from the main campaign and you can download other maps from the workshop but that's about all the content you get.
For the most part though the pathfinding is fine but it can be a little hit or miss especially in cramped areas with a large army.  There are "hero" missions where you play as one character, (you might can rescue others in the level but you start with just your character) that are more tedious than challenging, but they're also a kind of relief because they're still pretty easy and give valuable tech points for the campaign.
Overall, the game isn't perfect but it's still a very neat game and still fun to pop into here and there.

negative.review:
There are a lot of fun things about they are billions, but its clear somewhere along the way they ran out of money or time. The final campaign mission is laughable at how bad it is, it starts off great as a final mission thats built up on a campaign thats too short in mission variety but too long in play time. Then it decides to throw massive BS waves at you randomly, ensuring you have to pray the enemies attack you in a nice spot or else it's several hours wasted.

 Not only that but a good chunk of the game has you doing hero missions. These missions can only be described as boring and a waste of time. It's a shame they're basically mandatory to get the required research points you need. The game would straight up be better without it. Add in bugs, clipping errors, and a lack of enemy and unit variety, and you have an alright game, but an alright game that LOVES to waste your time.

It was fun until I got about 10 missions into the campaign and now even on the lowest difficulty I cannot continue the game even though I am a decent strategy player. I like the art style and thought it was fun in general, but it gets unfair and not fun at a pretty early point in the campaign. I spent too many hours retrying several strategies, missions, etc. but it didn't matter. I've never stopped playing a game for its difficulty, or left a bad review for it, but, the fact that I cannot continue the game past this point no matter what, constitutes a negative review.

One of the biggest complaints of the campaign is the fact that if you are losing a mission, you cannot save scum. I can understand why because the player would inevitably spend their time save scumming trying to change the result rather than restarting the map and adjusting their strategy. But the problem with that is you cannot reset your character or research trees after you have played a single mission with the points you have spent. This means that you cannot adjust your strategy at all in the campaign because you have made objectively bad choices in the research tree picks. The only solution is to lower the difficulty of the mission to progress which ruins the whole experience for the player. This punishes new players and since there is a meta, it only caters to those that enjoy the game THAT much to replay it.

The concept of the game is good, the implementation is bad locking the player into their choices. It really hurts new players especially.

The character missions whilst initially interesting became incredibly tedious and boring by the end, made worse by not picking the right talents in the talent tree which made it impossible to progress in missions without lowering the difficulty. In the end, I just rushed the character missions on the easiest mode. Add to the fact that you need to visually scour the map for items for the research and campaign points each mission which can turn a 10 minute mission into a an hour long mission as you're scouring every single room for objects you missed. This is made worse by the fact that there is no set position for the objects so guides don't help. They are randomly generated from a pool of locations each time the mission starts. So you could fail the mission and redo it only to find that the objects are in completely different locations.

As a new player, if you find a guide to follow of what skill and research points to pick, you can enjoy the game. But if you want to play this properly, you won't enjoy it as the developers actively punish you for not having spent a hundred hours prior playing the game and gaining all the knowledge needed before you even bought it. And lowering the difficulty to complete a mission just isn't fun as you cannot fix your strategy if you cannot even rectify the points wasted on bad choices.

The game itself is not bad. Its the little things that tick me off.

First off, pathfinding is terrible. Units get stuck running while another fires and doesnt move or attempt to walk around it. Its easy to get units stuck.

Next is the pacing. The game is slow except during attacks, the economy moves far too slow so starting each mission is a chore. The advances take forever and each building takes a lot of time to build. So if a mission tells you to wait until a certain day, its going to be a long and boring play.

Then and finally, its the campaign. The design is horribly made, you cant go back on your investments so you can easily softlock yourself if you go on to a mission without certain techs unlocked. Its just bad design. Not to mention the bloody game sets you up telling you a horde is coming from somewhere, and bullsh*t, it comes from the other side, and ruins the game for you.

Its a good game, but these details eventually killed the experience for me.

Meh, just meh. Like... there is some fun gameplay to be had in here, but it's really lacking in quality of life stuff. Even something as basic as a "restart mission" button is missing, meaning that if you hit a point of no return, you just have to sit and wait for your command center to be destroyed. That is such a basic thing that I almost can't believe any game of this type wouldn't have it (maybe it's there and just hidden in some really weird place? who knows). And that example is pretty emblematic of the game overall. It probably could have used a bit more time in the oven (or a patch maybe?) for things like that.

That's another thing, that's lacking: good info on what's going on. There don't appear to be actual numerical stats for my units, so I have to just go off vibes for deciding which one is better to use, which is weird. Plus even though there are callouts for when your base is under attack, I have, on more than one occasion not realized anything was wrong until one of my wall sections had already been completely destroyed and my base in shambles. Maybe that one is just a me problem, I don't know. 

Additionally the writing just isn't good at all unfortunately. And for a game like this, who cares I guess, but it would have been cool to actually have some reason to care about the events of the campaign. Especially when you factor in the need for solo hero unit missions, that seem like they should be "story missions" (a la StarCraft) but instead, they are just busywork missions. It would probably be a nice way of mixing things up to have these missions where you aren't doing the normal RTS thing in between regular ones, but they are just lame, so it becomes a chore.

And there are more little things I won't get into, but the point is, while any one or even two of these things i could probably just overlook and still have fun, when you add them all up it's just really hard to have a good time with this game. Many people seem to have enjoyed it, but it really seems like the game was going out its way to try to stop me from finding that fun and ultimately I just feel like it's not worth it.

PS: There are still a lot of good ideas in here, and the fact that there definitely is fun to be found underneath all of the annoyances says a lot. I'd call this pretty okay for a first game and I hope the devs keep honing their craft and make an even better one next time :)

PS: There are still a lot of good ideas in here, and the fact that there definitely is fun to be found underneath all of the annoyances says a lot. I'd call this pretty okay for a first game and I hope the devs keep honing their craft and make an even better one next time :)

One of the biggest complaints of the campaign is the fact that if you are losing a mission, you cannot save scum. I can understand why because the player would inevitably spend their time save scumming trying to change the result rather than restarting the map and adjusting their strategy. But the problem with that is you cannot reset your character or research trees after you have played a single mission with the points you have spent. This means that you cannot adjust your strategy at all in the campaign because you have made objectively bad choices in the research tree picks. The only solution is to lower the difficulty of the mission to progress which ruins the whole experience for the player. This punishes new players and since there is a meta, it only caters to those that enjoy the game THAT much to replay it.

The concept of the game is good, the implementation is bad locking the player into their choices. It really hurts new players especially.

The character missions whilst initially interesting became incredibly tedious and boring by the end, made worse by not picking the right talents in the talent tree which made it impossible to progress in missions without lowering the difficulty. In the end, I just rushed the character missions on the easiest mode. Add to the fact that you need to visually scour the map for items for the research and campaign points each mission which can turn a 10 minute mission into a an hour long mission as you're scouring every single room for objects you missed. This is made worse by the fact that there is no set position for the objects so guides don't help. They are randomly generated from a pool of locations each time the mission starts. So you could fail the mission and redo it only to find that the objects are in completely different locations.

As a new player, if you find a guide to follow of what skill and research points to pick, you can enjoy the game. But if you want to play this properly, you won't enjoy it as the developers actively punish you for not having spent a hundred hours prior playing the game and gaining all the knowledge needed before you even bought it. And lowering the difficulty to complete a mission just isn't fun as you cannot fix your strategy if you cannot even rectify the points wasted on bad choices.

The game itself is not bad. Its the little things that tick me off.

First off, pathfinding is terrible. Units get stuck running while another fires and doesnt move or attempt to walk around it. Its easy to get units stuck.

Next is the pacing. The game is slow except during attacks, the economy moves far too slow so starting each mission is a chore. The advances take forever and each building takes a lot of time to build. So if a mission tells you to wait until a certain day, its going to be a long and boring play.

Then and finally, its the campaign. The design is horribly made, you cant go back on your investments so you can easily softlock yourself if you go on to a mission without certain techs unlocked. Its just bad design. Not to mention the bloody game sets you up telling you a horde is coming from somewhere, and bullsh*t, it comes from the other side, and ruins the game for you.

Its a good game, but these details eventually killed the experience for me.
